body: In response to a "shortage of decent, safe and sanitary housing in the City of Los Angeles resulting in a critically low vacancy factor," the city council effectively prohibits most rent increases on residential properties for a six month period. The ordinance is set to expire April 30, 1979.
title: LA reacts to lack of housing by freezing rents for six months

body: The Beverly Hills City Council follows Los Angeles and approves a rent stabilization measure to counter "a critically low vacancy rate, which contributed to a substantial and rising number of exorbitant rental rate increases."
title: Bevery Hills approves a rent stabilization ordinance

body: Voters in Santa Monica approve a rent stablization ordinance in response to a shortage of housing units, low vacancy rates and rapidly rising rents. A Rent Control Board is tasked with implementing and enforcing the ordinance.
title: Santa Monica implements RSO
readmoresource: City of Santa Monica Rent Control Board

body: With its six month prohibition on rent increases set to expire, the Los Angeles City Council adopts a rent stabilization ordinance to address a shortage of safe and affordable housing.
title: LA formally adopts RSO

body: Voters approve the Palm Springs Rent Control Ordinance as an initiative. The Desert Political Action Committee provides support for getting the ordinance on the April 1980 ballot and promoting its adoption.
title: Palm Springs adopts RSO

body: Thousand Oaks implements a rent stabilization ordinance that covers a small number of apartments units and all mobile homes.
title: Thousand Oaks adopts RSO

body: In response to a state supreme court ruling that landlords cannot evict tenants if they wish to stop being a landlord, the state legislature adopts the Ellis Act. The act allows landlords to evict tenants if the property owners remove the property from the rental market. Municipalities are given some level of regulation of the Ellis Act.
title: State legislators approve the Ellis Act

body: The L.A. City Council approves a rent stabilization ordinance. Under the ordinance, residential rent levels are regulated, housing services provided with the unit must be maintained, and specific maintenance standards must be met. The ordinance also protects tenants from certain types of eviction and harassment by the landlord.
title: West Hollywood implements RSO

body: The city council adds to its rent stabilization ordinance, which stipulates that tenants who paid $600 or more per month at move-in are subject to Chapter 6 regulations adopted Oct. 7, 1986.
title: Bevery Hills amends its ordianance

body: After a study finds a vacancy rate of less than 1.5 percent, the Thousand Oaks City Council gives tentative approval to amending its rent stabilization ordinance and capping rent increases at 7 percent for all apartments.
title: Thousand Oaks moves to impose rent caps on all apartments

body: The Thousand Oaks City Council reverses course on its stricter rent control measures after a landlord threatens to begin the eviction process against more than 500 tenants. The council does pass an amendment that continues to regulate rent for some 800 rental units currently covered by rent stabilization.
title: Thousand Oaks backs down after approving stricter rent control measures

body: Generally, Costa-Hawkins prevents rental units constructed after Feb. 1, 1995, from being regulated by rent stabilization ordinances and keeps already exempt rental units as such. Also, under Costa-Hawkins landlords are allowed to raise rents if and when the unit becomes vacant.
title: Costa-Hawkins Rental Act prevents new rental units from falling under rent stablization ordinances
